availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects

note.p: 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' is a Middle Gaelic verse litany, praising and invoking the protection of seven archangels (one for each of the seven days of the week) and the twelve apostles. It was probably composed in Ireland but inscribed around 1500 on the flyleaf of Egerton 2899,, a Psalter belonging to the Campbells of Glenorchy. It shows little to no influence from Scottish Gaelic but was evidently valued in the elite learned culture of Argyll at the time.

msContents.summary: A Middle Gaelic lorica poem; otherwise, the manuscript contains a martyrology with Scottish focus and a Psalter.

filiation.p:
Thomas O'Nolan (1912) has edited 'Aingil Dé dom dhín', although without using Egerton 2899. Instead, he used eight Irish manuscripts:
Dublin, Royal Irish Academy, MS 23.P.16 (1230), 15th cent., An Leabhar Breac
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Laud Misc. 615, 16th century
Dublin, Royal Irish Academy, MS 23.G.23 (256), 17th century
Dublin, Royal Irish Academy, MS 23.N.13 (???), date unknown
Maynooth, St Patrick’s College, Murphy MS. 70, date unknown
Maynooth, St Patrick’s College, Murphy MS. 39, date unknown
Maynooth, St Patrick’s College, O’Renehan MS. 96, date unknown
A copy in the O’Curry Mss. (unspecified), 19th century
The number and order of the quatrains in the different manuscript versions varies quite significantly. This can be used to show Egerton 2899’s affiliation in the tradition.

The Egerton 2899 text thus seems to align structurally with the Leabhar Breac and Laud Misc. 615 texts. This is not particularly borne out by a comparison between the varia lectiones in O'Nolan's edition, however. While the Egerton 2899 text never closely aligns in any serious way with the others against the Leabhar Breac and Laud Misc. 615, it often presents its own distinctive readings against them.

It seems fairly likely that the omission of q7 was a mistake at a certain point in the tradition. qq5–7 list seven archangels, describing each of them as a “crown” (cor). q8 then calls them “the seven crowns on the head of God” (Seacht cuir dar cend De). Given that three of these crowns (Raphael, Painiel, and Gabriel) are enumerated in q7, it was almost certainly in the original composition. The Leabhar Breac, Laud Misc. 615, and Egerton 2899 texts thus all have a common ancestor somewhere below the archetype where this omission occured. This archetype must have existed by the period 1408×1411, when the Leabhar Breac was produced.

From the evidence of textual history, attestation in the manuscript record and language (see below), we can conclude that the poem was originally composed in Ireland, probably in the Middle Gaelic period.

note.p: In the linguistic survey that follows, I focus on the Egerton 2899 text of 'Aingil Dé dom dhin'.

The text may have been written originally in early Middle Gaelic, as it preserves some forms and is largely compliant with the norms of Middle Gaelic. However, there are several Early Modern forms that possibly appeared during the poem's transmission or possibly call for the dating of its composition later in the Middle Gaelic period rather than earlier. While the poem was inscribed in Argyll by a Scottish scribe, there seems to be negligible influence from Scottish Gaelic.

It should be noted that the poem does not provide a great deal of linguistic data that could be used to ascertain date or provenance; it includes relatively few verbs, for example, and makes no references to secular history.

Old Gaelic or conservative Middle Gaelic features include:
A long a-preterite is retained: do róith (:"cáich") (q12a.
Continued use of infixed pronouns: e.g. rom féith ('who watches over me'), q6b, but see also q26b; nachum gabsat gaí ('spears that did not transfix me'). q27b; ním ria ('wil not reach me')q12c.
Old Gaelic 1st plural present, atchiam (:biadh, q1b.
Old Gaelic 3rd singular future, ním ria ('wil not reach me')q12c, although eDILhas examples of ria from Early Modern Gaelic poetry.

Later Middle and Early Modern Gaelic features include:
Object pronoun used with verb other than the copula: fetheat me ('may they watch over me')q26b.
Subject pronoun used with verb other than the copula: nach mhillter me tríbh ('that I am not troubled through them'), q3b
Elision occurs on 8/10 instances where elision would be possible in Early Modern Gaelic: 1b, 6d, 8d, 12c, 12d, 18c, 20c, 25d, ; the two exceptions are 9c and 29b

Possible signs of Scottish Gaelic influence :
One instance of the object of fri being in the dative: "re bais bhan", q17d,

Resistance of Scottish Gaelic influence:
'Irish' passive form used; e.g., gebhar leam gach laí ('is seized on by me each day'), q7d.
Numerals 7-10 still nasalise: e.g., Seacht nárćhaingíl ('seven archangels'), q2a.
'Irish' eclipsis is used: parrthalon na b[p]eann ('Parrthalón of the pains'), q20b
It should be noted that these are merely examples of the different influences on the text and are not proportional to one another. The bulk of the text seems to be Middle Gaelic.

physDesc.p: NB: The following description only covers the transcribed sections of the manuscript.

foliation.p: Modern; poem is inscribed on what was intended as the flyleaf.

condition.p: The condition is very good; the entire text is perfectly legible.

provenance.p: According to Flower (1926: 23), Egerton 2899 began life in the 14th century as a Psalter. About a century later, this was joined by a tabulated martyrology. The latter’s emphasis is on Scottish saints, some very local to Argyll. This, combined with an inscription implying that the manuscript was the property of Colin Campbell, Laird of Glenorchy (d. 1523), and a 18th-century bookplate of his descendants, the Earls of Breadalbane suggests an Argyll provenance for the gathering containing the martyrology. 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' would have been added in this context (around 1500). Technically, the Psalter could be from elsewhere.

metDecl.p: The poem's metre is rannaigecht bec (51, 51, 51, 51). The text is laid out with one quatrain per line in Egerton 2899.

refsDecl.p: References are to quatrain (qn; the <lg> element>) then to line (abcd; the <l> element).
